title: Riot Preseason 6 Balancing Staretgy
body: I think I realized the balancing strategy based on the last couple Red posts. While they tried to balance some things, for the most part they are throwing out a bunch of changes, expecting a lot of balance problems and such. Then they are going to nit pick through the system and solve issues that pop up until we end up with a changed, potentially better League of Legends. At least, that's what I see going on here.

replies.body: That's the hope. Preseason's a bit different to other times of the year, in that we're much more focused on getting bigger changes (new masteries, big sets of item changes, game pacing etc) as good foundations to support balanced characters, than in trying to give each individual champion exactly the right numbers on day one. Foundation building, with a focus on the longer term, rather than a patch that focuses on short term balance. That's an approach that's normally not appropriate, given there's ranked play and the various competitive leagues being played on a regular patch. Preseason's the time where we can make bigger, long term improvements, even if that means some disruption in the short term though. Demonstrating what the effects of healing via crits are for example, to set up work for the coming year, is more important than a handful of champions being suddenly too strong or weak for a patch.

Why would you intentionally make the game agonizing to play for several patches instead of making small, good changes as time goes on?

The changes in the preseason are all pretty heavily intertwined. Some things can't be broken down into smaller chunks. Doing just a couple of new items at a time won't work without the appropriate adjustments to the rest of the item system for example, since the new ones will be either too good or too weak if they're not in sync with the overall system. Additionally many components are heavily dependent on others. Marksmen kit updates for example are dependent on overhauling AD itemization and vice versa for example - the new items were developed with the updated kits in mind, and those kits were developed within a context of improved AD itemization. Things like Masteries could have been separated out, but that then means going through a period of significant disruption, balancing the game after those changes and then doing the same thing again shortly after. There's a limited window we've got where we're not impacting ranked or pro play, so getting stuff in right at the start of that and then taking as much time as available to improve's really valuable.

A lot of people have been complaining about Yasuo and Tryndamere's synergy with the new crit healing mastery, but I think a lot of people missed that Ashe's passive was changed to not be broken with it. Was that change made specifically to fix her interaction with the new mastery and {{item:3508}}, or was it changed for another reason and those are just happy accidents?

We were extremely confident Ashe would be a problem with Warlord's Bloodlust, so that was a major factor in updating her passive.

Trynd and Yasuo were both identified as characters that would likely be too strong, by how much and in what ways we should react wasn't sufficiently clear pre patch to justify changes to them in advance however. In cases like that we feel we often get more valuable from releasing and responding quickly as needed than in pre-empting things, especially since occasionally the need's misidentified. Despite expectations Vlad and Rumble would gain significant power from the AP update in 5.13 for example we chose to wait and assess what changes were needed. To our surprise the performance of both champions actually decreased, leaving us very happy we hadn't preemptively nerfed them.

Kind of along this line, but with {{item:3123}} return and the increased lifesteal it really seems like Riot is favoring the concept of OP healing being countered by OP anti-healing. I'm kind of disappointed with this as I was hoping with the removal of {{item:3123}} and the changes to {{item:3152}} that you guys were in the process of removing GW and instead normalizing heals to make them balanced without having to counter them. Is there a particular gameplay/feel reason you are opting for the more extreme route?
I would like an answer to this question....

Doesn't the fact that so many champions synergize _**so well**_ with particular end level talents completely defeat the point of trying to offer a 'meaningful' choice about playing the game the way you want? 

So far in all my tests only about 10% of the champions I've thought "there is more than one viable option here".

As long as we are discussing patch balance, might I ask what prompted the nerfs to jungle gold gain while buffing the minion gold gain? The net loss for junglers is bigger than ever, and they were already the lowest income role aside from support!
I mean, I'll probably get people bashing me for this, but if you are supposed to be spending most of your  time trying to gank lanes, should't you be profiting more from the periods when you can sneak in some farm, rather than losing out on income even in the case you dedicate to it?

This might seem little, as it's just a 20 gold loss per camp, but it's very important, especially for junglers with low kill potential/weak early game (as the lanes enter midgame far before the jungler can, and compounded by the fact only a few junglers have the ability to gank as well as a mid laner can, with a mix of CC, burst and gap closers).

So I'll pass on preseason if it's all the same to you.

Meddler, what is your opinion on the other 4 ADCs that got big updates (MF, Cait , Quinn and Corki ) ? You said Koggy is going to need some help and Graves is going to need nerfs, but what about the other 4, what do you think of their state of balance ?

Disclaimer: This is a really, really rough early assessment.

MF - Potentially too strong
Cait - Seems to be in a reasonable spot so far?
Corki - Seeing really variable performance so hard to say anything yet (some people using the changes well, some failing pretty hard)
Quinn - Seeing people struggle a bit given how her pattern's changed, some people utilizing it well are very effective though. If I had to guess I'd say she might be on the strong side, that's very much a personal guess though.

Time will tell but I think Kindred got hit too hard this patch. From bordering top tier to now being a liability (she was always risky- feed/famine jungler imo). She hasn't benefited early game as much as the other ADCs with all these changes and felt the jungle nerfs (noticeably harder clears, nerfed health, and changed jungle items and masteries). Add to that the increase in game speed and the nature of her damage being tied to her stacking her passive (doesn't have time to "ramp up"), I'm afraid she'll be even more situational. Hell Graves seems to be a better jungler at the moment with same or greater mobility and higher base stats and scaling. Please keep on eye on Kindred and make sure she stays relevant. It would be sad to see her make her debut and be thrown off the thrown of/stripped of her title of  marksman jungler so soon.

MF potentially too strong ? are you serious now? I'm sorry, but her passive feels terrible and the update didn't fix any of her problems, yet you claiming she's potentially too strong ? I don't know, I gave up on her, she just doesn't feel satisfying at all
That may be true for you, but the numbers 100% point towards her being insanely strong. like 5900 damage on a late game ult strong. Like 350%AD crits strong.

Can you comment on where mages are at? If they're too weak, which direction would you take? Revert the cost of items, buff their keystone masteries (could there be more for mages?), return mana pots, or just strictly nerf the AD changes? I feel like there's a lot of different levers to pull, so I'm wondering which is the most practical. I think mages feel weak, but whether they actually are is a different matter.

From the impressions I've been getting, the player feedback I've heard is more like this:

* MF - Weaker than before, her damage is lower and her item-path is less flexible.
* Cait - Just 'meh', quick traps can create zoning, but can still be played around just like before and the nerfs to Q, E and her AS make her less safe when that does occur, not to mention the removal of the traps' damage makes people just step on all 5 one after another with no qualms.  Honestly, I'm confused at how metal teeth clamping down onto your leg somehow doesn't cause injury.
* Corki - The modifying of hits autos into half magic dmg makes itemizing against him easier, whilst the range nerfs to Valkyrie makes it even easier to assassinate him, especially considering he still suffers from the previous mana cost nerfs.  MS from The Package may be too overbearing to play against, but the enhanced Valkyrie is awkward to use and at times self-contradictory.
* Quinn - Just straight-up nerfed.  She's worse in every role played, top, mid, ADC.  Her kit changes clash hard with her item-path making it factually impossible to optimize her in any way.  She essentially doesn't have an R, it's been replaced with a mount from Heroes of the Storm, except far worse since it can't be used until level 6 and costs an absurd amount of mana.

When you nerf MF can you please look into the timing of her AAs with Love Tap. Her auto attack timing was pretty much the only reason I played MF before the rework and there is no reason it should be different when you Love Tap.

I honestly really like the changes to Quinn, her best playstyle I feel now is to weave auto attacks and spells together. With this, she's become SUPER strong. And also, her mobility is stupid op. Like, absolutely ridiculous. But I see people trying to still use it mostly for the damage rather than for the passenger airplane it is. So yeah, maybe that's where people are still failing.

Also, I really feel like Valor is such an integral part of your fights now. I have more control on when Harrier comes up, so when I go all in I feel like it's actually a 2v1 (Quinn AND Valor) rather than just Quinn with some bird shaped missile.

Isn't this how you approached the juggernaut updates?

I'm fine with a chaotic short term as compensation for a stable long term.  Keep up the good work!
isnt that more of what PBE is for, though? as far as i know not a single balance change was made to the first set of changes on PBE

PBE gives us some really valuable feel, direction and thematic feedback. It's got a very small playerbase compared to the regular servers though, which tends to lead to some really lopsided games in terms of team composition (e.g. silver and diamond in the same game). That, when combined with the fact that people play much less seriously on the PBE, means its value from a balance perspective's pretty limited. We do get some useful stuff there, and there were changes to quite a lot of preseason elements while they were on PBE, it's not realistic to expect the PBE or internal testing to deliver sufficient balance feedback to polish changes of this scope however.
